content.description:
Researchers have undertaken a long-term study of populations of rock pocket mice, Chaetodipus intermedius, in Arizona and New Mexico. Rock pocket mouse fur is either dark or light in color. Most of the populations studied live in areas with light-colored granite rocks; however, some areas are dominated by dark-colored rocks from ancient lava flows. Researchers collected mice from six sites in Arizona and recorded their coat colors. Figure 1 shows the study sites, the rock colors, and the distribution of coat colors.

Figure 1. Rock color and coat color at three sites on a lava flow (West, Mid, and East), and three nearby sites: O’Neill Hills (O’Neill), the Tule Mountains (Tule), and Christmas Pass (Xmas)

In the Arizona populations, the melanocortin-1 receptor <math alttext="or M C l R" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>(</mtext><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mtext>MC</mtext></mstyle><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle><mtext>R</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene is responsible for coat color phenotype (light or dark). The <math alttext="M C l R D" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext></mtext><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>MC</mtext><mn>1</mn><mtext>R</mtext><mo>⁢</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.20em"></mspace></mrow></mstyle><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mtext>D</mtext></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> allele, which results in a dark coat, is dominant to the <math alttext="d" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> allele. Researchers collected samples of mice from all six study sites and sequenced the <math alttext="M C l R" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>M</mi><mi>C</mi><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> gene. They also collected mice with dark coats from a location in New Mexico, the Carrizozo lava flow, to determine if the <math alttext="M C l R" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>M</mi><mi>C</mi><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>gene was also responsible for the dark coat colors observed in that population. The rock pocket mouse population in Carrizozo is isolated from the populations in Arizona. Table 1 presents the genotypic data from sampled mice from all seven locations.

content.question: Which of the following best describes the processes occurring between the mouse populations and their environments?

choices.label: Natural selection favors the mice with the dark coat color, causing the mice in all of the populations to be better adapted.
Natural selection favors the mice with the light coat color, causing the mice in all of the populations to be better adapted.
Dark color is selected for in mice from the West, Mid, and East populations.
Light color is selected for in mice from the West, Mid, and East populations.

content.answer: Dark color is selected for in mice from the West, Mid, and East populations.
